This interaction only works this way with the Training dummies with how Urgots Execute Dmg is Calculated.
It goes something like it does the enemy target amount of dmg if it lives after that it does 10 extra dmg, then 100 then 1k until some number above 1 million.

Target Dummies dont die so the dmg number and the healing get to a really high number, while real champions get executed and you only heal 15% of the current hp the enemy champion had at time of execution.

This is the key: target dummies don't die, so the execute mechanic deals vast quantities of true damage in its attempt to kill the target. Executing a champ in an ordinary match would result in healing for 15% of their current health, plus a bit more if they have a shield.

That said, has anyone tried this against a target affected by Tryn's or Kayle's ult? In theory, it should have the same effect.

from the lol wiki:

To ensure death, the execution first deals 100% current health as true damage, then, if the target is still alive, increases by additional cycles of true damage in powers of ten from 10 up to 10^6, for a maximum damage of 1.111.110.
Only the target's current health will count as Urgot's damage in post-game statistics and spell vamp healing.
A target with at least 1,111,111 Hybrid resistances icon shield would survive this damage, with its remaining HP depending only on the excess of its shielding.

Tested it out with Urgot in the practice tool against a Brand. Even with his RoA fully stacked, your ult barely heals you for any damage because he needs to be below 25% max health, and it only deals his current health in true damage when executing. I tried the same with Pyke and got the same results, though with even less healing because of Pyke's R being an AoE and thus gaining reduced healing.

The way these types of executes work is that they deal the champion's HP in true damage first, then, if they're still alive, they start to deal more and more true damage until they die. If, for instance, the enemy has a Janna shield on them, the first phase would leave them with only the amount of health the shield had. Then, it would start to deal larger and larger amounts of true damage in order to finish the job. It doesn't start at dealing 9999999 damage, it only increases to that amount if the target doesn't die quickly. Since practice dummies don't die, and can take an infinite amount of damage, you immediately deal the maximum damage an execute can deal, and heal for a small percentage of a very very large number.
